text: Pour on tap at Black Bottle, dark orange almost reddish pour with off white head, aroma brought notes of yeast, dough, lots of clove and coriander into a bit of sweet banana, bread, vanilla, slight grass and orange peel comes through. Taste was a mix of orange, grass, pine into a bit of yeast, dough, spices with clove, touch of banana, some earth, finishing slightly spicy, slightly sweet.

12 oz. bottle from 2011 Beer Camp mix pack that had just arrived at retailer. Served in a pint glass. [from notes].

A: The beer pours a hazed golden orange color with a super creamy and very high bone-colored head. Head has excellent retention and more than 2 pours were required to get this in my glass. {A 2nd bottle only produced a modest but durable white head} Cloudy, unfiltered look. Limited lacing.

S: Yeasty and wheaty with clove, citrus and banana tones. Perhaps not bad for style but not to my taste.

T: Low levels of bitter, sweet and sour largely in balance, but with a sweet start and a sour finish. Hints of citrus under clove, banana, and light malt. Well done but not really my cup of tea. 

M: medium/thin body; low but fine carbonation; after a bit of crispness initially it is quite soft

O: My first beer from the Beer Camp. Given my love for Sierra Nevada Brewing, this one was a little disappointing but ... Not a favorite style, but clearly a step above average for style IMO.

(revised 6/15/2011 with 2nd tasting)

Backlog rating. Keg at CBC Islington tap takeover, London. It pours a clean brown color with ruby edges and a small beige head. Aroma is malty and sweet, with notes of biscuit, caramel, licorice, light citrus notes, light booze. Taste is sweet, with notes of banana, toffee, biscuit, burnt sugar. Finishes lightly yeasty and estery. Medium bodied with soft carbonation. Overall, nice bock
Draft - pours a hazy golden yellow . Sweet wheat aroma . Taste is yeasty with sweet malts , mild alcohol . Not bad .

poured a hazy darker version of the kellerweiss. good beer...full bavarian hefe aroma with some roasted sweet grain bock qualities as well. one of the better done WBs ive had. full flavored and balanced. 5/11 update - as beer camp beer #37, it was even better than i remember. huge flavors and aroma, well balanced. possibly the best 12-ouncer Sierra Nevada has put out. Love it!"
Tawny colored pour. Small off white head. Little lacing. Nutty aroma with banana and roasted malt taste.

On draft at Mad Mex. Cloudy, light brown color with a little white head with some lacing left on the glass. Aroma is somewhat muted, clove, fruity, slightly nutty smell. Taste is more prevalent, with the banana taste up front, earthy, dark fruity flavor on the backend. Good beer overall....so good, I had 2. Would recommend to others.
Pours muddy light brown with a low off white head. Aromas of toffee, banana, apricot, apple. Taste is apple, banana, apricot, slight caramel. Mouthfeel is creamy with medium carbonation.
Tap at Happy Gnome. Hazy light amber pour with a frothy white head. Lots of banana and clove in this. Smooth malty palate. Really good.
(tap) clear light brown colour with a small brown head; aroma of sweet fruit; balanced flavour

Keg Sheffield tap. Great murky hazy brown colour thin white head. Aroma is mild banana cloves. Taste is banana cloves slight cinnamon spice long bitter finish. Nice mouthfeel medium full body. Good example of this style.

Pours a finger of head on a cloudy brown colored body.
The aroma is caramel and apple cider. Interesting but good.
The taste is a mild bitter start with a late malt sweetness. Great balance.
The texture is smooth with moderate carbonation.
Quite enjoyable.

On tap half pint at Gilly's Beer & Fine Wine in Rockville, MD. 

Murky, rusty brown amber with a small creamy pale khaki head and excellent lacing. 

Aroma of caramel, orange, banana, cloves, brown sugar, apricot and yeast. 

Taste of toffee, cloves, banana, spices and bitter orange. 

Medium/full body and low/medium carbonization.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Tap at Dada, Sheffield. Ugly, murky, chicken gravy looking colour. Tight, off white head. Cinammon. Mashed up, ripe banana. Clove. All of that.

Keg at craft Clerko. It pours murky brown with a small beige head. The nose is earthy, brown bread, spice, cloves, brown sugar, bruised banana and aniseed. The taste is toasty, earth, bruised banana, light spice, touch of alcohol, caramel, faint aniseed with a dry finish. Medium body and fine, prickly carbonation. Not bad. For a weizenbock.

Apple ciderish in looks you can just barely make out your fingers on the far side of the glass. Smells like banana. Taste like a spiced creamy banana with a mealy mouth-feel. Not my favorite style but i still enjoyed it.
bottle. light brown with small head. packed with the flavors of a hefeweizen on steroids. absolutely delicious.
A damn fine beer! Quaffable, flavorful and a great body. A delectable clove/banana nose. Malted spices rolling to bananas flambeau that finishes with a dance of biscuit and toasted sugar.

Basically a hefe on overload-bubble gum, clove, banana-with some dark malt backbone. Really nice.

On draft. A murky light brown. Slight banana aroma. Sweet taste of cloves and bananas. A really nice American version of the style.
A wonderful beer. Pours a reddish brown. Nice lacing. Great banana and clove aromas and flavors. Almost heady banana cream pie. Great stuff.
On draft at Rustico in Arlington VA. Pours a murky brown with an off white head. Fruity nose. Flavors of caramel with some tart apple notes. Smooth slightly tart finish.
Well executed version of the style. Nice and malty, beautiful foamy weizen head, deep malt/grain character, smooth yet potent. Yummy!

Medium brown cloudy color with large off-white head and nice lacing. Aroma and flavor have nice banana, spices, and yeastiness with sweet caramel malt finish. Medium mouthfeel, and very flavorfol. Pretty good overall.

Big beautiful bock. Maybe a little chill haze from draught but the aroma and appearance tell you what you're getting in to: a big full palate of malty goodness with the right amount of hops to clean things up and do it again.
Had off tap at wob. Dark cloudy brown. Raisin, spicy pepper, caramel and banana. Middle Sweetens Out And Finishes Full With A pleasant Balanced Alcohol, malt, And dryness.

Draft at Rustico Alexandria, 4 ounce pour. Hazy dark caramel brown color with off-white head. Aromas of caramel, white fruit, light dark fruit, wheat. Tastes of wheat, malt, caramel, dark fruit, white fruit. Medium-light body with a dry finish.

On tap at The Village Idiot. Pours murky light brown with deep golden highlights and small beige head. Aroma is nice banana, medium body, medium carbonation, and good small bubble lacing. Taste is really bready, some banana, some grainy, and bubblegum. Too bready to be my favorite for the style.

Draft at Good Dog. Tulip. Very cloudy amber with a large frothy white head. Toasted wheat notes. Banana bread. Tamarind. Green tomatoes. Mangos. Apricot pits. Bamboo. Cloves. Elephant ear mushrooms. Tangelos. Touch sour up front. Earthy full citrus body. Fruity dry finish. In no way a typical Weizenbock. Bigger and better.

Draft pour into a wine glass. Pours a murky copper color with an off white head of foam. The aroma is papery, musty, and maybe a little spicy. Taste is more musty paper. This one really didnt do much for me. Medium body with medium carbonation.
(Backlog) Cloudy, orange ear wax color. Thicker cream colored head. The smell is heavy fruits, banana, esters, some wheat in there as well. The taste is wheat, fruits, banana.

Draught... and probably my favorite example of a style I really dislike. Pours a brown color thats very cloudy, and almost no head on it. Nose is muddy and earthy with some citrus in there. Taste was also a little sweet with the citrus elements coming through. Not a huge fan, but drinkable.
Draft - never thought Id find this, let alone on tap. Light for the style with an orange presence. Spicy finish.

Pint on tap. Cloudy and opaque brown with a small film of cream. Mild nose of caramel, banana and dry grass. Tastes of clove, bubblegum, wheat, banana, sourish caramel apple and a finish of dry grass and light citrus. Medium body has medium-high but mostly smooth carbonation. Malty and sweet but finishes dry enough to nearly check the sweetness.
On tap at Global Brew. Pours a turbid brown with a thin light tan head. Mild maple syrup aroma. Taste is maple roasted malt and a nice sourness. Quite good, but not a weizenbock stylistically.

On tap at State Line tasting. Poursa cloudy straw yellow color with a pillowy white head. Aroma is light banana, with a background of clove, and a bready malt base. Flavor has spicey notes up front- allspice and moderate clove with apple esters and wheat bread flavors that emerge as the beer warms. Finish is crisp, clean, and dry. Light bodied, high carbonation.

4/4 for the pack. Bottled in early April.

A: Pours a hazy apricotesque ale with a single finger of light caramel head. This falls quickly to a sheet of the same. Some spotty lacing.

S: The wheat is king in this nose. Plenty of sweet wheat notes with bready, biscuity malt in the back. Some nice floral notes. The yeast is pretty traditional for the style - earthy, a little sharp, hints of clove. Oddly, the alcohol comes through on this one for me, not good.

T: A little overly yeasty on the palate. The wheat is fun, but adds a little too much sweetness. Some banana. The beer has all the basic parts to make up a nice weizenbock, but they just dont weave quite too well. They seem to all be in combat with one another, rather than weaving properly.

M: Thick with high carb. Long, sweet, wet finish.

O: As above, this has all the pieces, but the puzzle isnt quite finished here. If they took another crack at this, I would give it another go, but as it stands, not quite on the level I would expect for Sierra.

Serving type: bottle

05-10-2012

I grew up on the classic SN Pale having it around during high school, and since have watched SN grow into a national representation of incredible craft beer. Living 45 mins away is a treat for the random growler fill. Keep up the amazing work and thanks!

Hazy orange. Lots of yeast, lots of spice. Thick head. Slick mouthfeel. A very nice take on the style.

Just bought one 12 oz bottle from the case of craft singles. Just had it with a salami sandwich with my homemade mustard sauce, so delicious! So sad I just had one, and may have trouble finding more. Bought in Millis Ma.

Drank as part of the 2011 Sierra Nevada Beer Camp. Pours a very cloudy orange color with a thin, dense white head. Aroma has a lot orange citrus notes, banana, spicy clove with a nice sweetness that compliments the spices very nicely. Flavor has a nice mixture of banana and clove with a modest amount of alcohol sneaking in late. Well balanced, none of the flavors are overpowering as you can see in the weizen bock style at times. Modest body, low carbonation with a low alcohol kick. Overall a very good brew for the beer camp pack. Matches what I think the style should be.

12th June 2011Cloudy orange beer, small white head. Semi dry and semi soft palate. Tiny bit of caramel wheat gives way to banana, bubblegum and then some mild orange citrus. Finishes semi dry with a carbonated sting. Decent.

August 19th, 2011 -  Sierra Nevadas Weizenbock must have graduated from beer camp with flying colors, because it now appears to stand on its own on market shelves, proud and decorated. I remember it being an tasty, toothsome beer a year and a half ago, with its skillfully crafted emphasis on light, fruit flavors. Marmalade orange in color with a finger of a white-tan head, this looks like so many other summer beers I quaffed back in 2011. The smell sets it apart, with a dry aroma based on the weizenbocks particular grain composition, but also limned with juicy and acidic apricot. Fresh orange juice makes an appearance too, making this beer smell like a part of a well rounded breakfast. The flavor matches the aroma - a pleasant, fruity acidity like unripe apricots, a sharp and cutting palate (again, always good for cutting through summers dry mouth) and a long aftertaste that almost seems to ripen the fruits flavor the longer it lasts. Im not Sierra Nevadas head brewer (Pfff, I wish) but I can see why he made the decision to keep going with this alumnus of their Beer Camp.

I am not a big weizenbock drinker so maybe I was not ready for this but I have never had one that was so damn yeasty. Dark and turbid orange color. The smell was all yeast and bananas. The flavor was yeast, banana, clove, yeast, bubblegum, yeast. This was not bad but Id rather have a vitus any day of the week.

The beer is very slightly hazy and light orange hued, with a smallish head that leaves some caked on lacing on the pint glass. The aroma brings banana, sweet malt, fruit, wheat. The flavor is decent. Sweet and fruity, with emphasis on bananas. Medium-thin in body, with adequate carbonation. A decent beer, but not in the same league as Aventinus.

A-- Poured a hazy honey orange color. Lots of small carbonation bubbles on the sides of the glass. Quick fading white head that goes straight to film. Better head retention on swirling but still fades pretty quick. 

S-- Strong clove smell, followed with banana and then coriander. Good nose. 

T-- Spicy clove followed by more banana. Get a lot of banana cream pie taste with touches of coriander as well. 

M-- Prickly, active carbonation. Brimming with life. Finishes a bit dry and crisp with a dried banana taste. Medium feel to this. Very crisp and lively. 

O-- Good beer. Well made, very enjoyable even though this is not a style I am big on. Something I would very much buy again.

12 ounce bottle purchased a year ago at the Mira Mesa BevMo in the Sierra Nevada Beer Camp 12-pack ($17.99 for 12-pack).  Pours a cloudy straw color with a finger and a half of white foam.  Aroma of honey, light caramel, banana, yeastiness, and canned fruit in heavy syrup.  Flavor of caramel, honey, spice, and yeasty wheat bread.  Very nice level of sweetness here.  Spritzy carbonation enhances the flavor.  SN pulls off a great version of one of my favorite German styles...would like to see this in regular production.  (348, 715)

Bottle from Shawan Liquor. Pours golden with an inch of white foam that leaves traces of lacing. Theres fairly high amount of carbonation.  Theres bits of yeast floating around as well. Robust notes of fruit, clove, and yeast on the nose. Theres quite a bit of clove on the tongue as well. Finishes clean. Solid!

12-ounce bottle. Pours a very dense dark straw color with no head. mild banana aroma. Medium body. Wheaty flavor with slight bubble gum character and mild banana. Full mouthfeel. late sweetness and slight alcohol hint. Overall, clean and a nice weizen bock.

12 ounce bottle into weizen glass, bottled 4/5/2011.  Pours hazy golden orange color with a foamy 2 finger white head with good retention, that reduces to a thin lace.  Minimal wisps of lacing on the glass, with plenty of carbonation streaming up.  Aromas of big grape, banana, pear, clove, pepper, bread, wheat, herbal, floral, earth, and yeast spiciness.  Some pretty nice aromas that are a bit faint.  Taste of banana, clove, grape, lemon, bread, wheat, pepper, floral, herbal, earth, and yeast spices.  Quite dry on the finish; with small lingering notes of banana, bread, wheat, pepper, and earthy spiciness on the finish for a short bit.  Nice balance of flavors with decent complexity.  Medium carbonation and body; with a fairly creamy and slightly slick mouthfeel as expected.  Alcohol is well hidden with only a small warming noticed after the finish.  Very easy to drink as well.  Overall this is a nice weizen bock.  Nice flavor balance and very easy to drink.  It was not as robust as I was hoping for, and a it feels a bit basic.  Enjoyable, but lacks character.

Bottle courtesy of Duffman! Pours cloudy orange into my Maudite glass, recently un-retired, due to my inability to reach low shelves due to my knee injury.Head is moderate to thick, lacing is lovely. Nose is bright and full of lemon and biscuits, light hop notes play off of a cookie-like malt bill, reminiscent of my dear Gerat Aunts lemon cake, with a strong mineral undertone. Flavours of clean lemon, candy, tea, soft round fruit, very gentle in the mouth. Frankly quite impressed by this, for someone who REALLY dislikes Weizenbock as a general rule.

12 oz bottle pours hazy amber with a white head.  Aroma of citrus and pepper.  Taste is much the same.

Spicy  fruity aroma, poured more golden than other weizenbocks I have had. Very refreshing bold entrance, lemon, cloves, pineapple, and you get a yeasty sendoff as it goes down. Slight warmth at the finish. Well rounded mouthfeel, drinks thicker than it looks. Perfect brunch beer.

The aroma is sweet and malty with some spices (clove), banana, and yeast. There is no sign of alcohol in the nose whatsoever. The taste is equally as good as the aroma. The taste starts out with a lot of sweetness with some wheat and banana. The clove flavors come in next along with some yeast and a touch of warmth from the alcohol in the finish.

Pours hazy orange gold, small head. The aroma is fruity, floral and sweet and rather pleasing ! Taste is fruity and a bit spicy, a taste of banana and pineapple comes through. Thirst quenching, finish is dry and somewhat long. Quaff score 7 / 10

Pours gold with a white head and aroma of fruits, bananas, and wheat. Taste is of a fruit blend, with banana, wheat, and spices in the flavor and is sweet throughout. A nice brew with some good flavor.

Very cloudy, golden coloured body with a thin white head. Aroma of wheat, a ton of yeast, caster sugar, a touch of light fruits and a good fresh clean note. Medium to Full-bodied; Strong yeastie flavour with a lot of curacao, coriander seed, wheat, apricots and a touch of corn at the end. Aftertaste shows a good sweetness that lingers, only a hint of the alcohol and a great full bodied flavour with hints of complexity, but a smooth finish. Overall, a very well done weizenbock with a great set of flavours, nothing offensive and a pleasant finish - great to sample! I sampled this twelve ounce bottle purchased from La Bodega in Anchorage, Alaska on 23-June-2011 sampled at home in Washington on the opposite end of the country on 07-February-2012.

In short: A pale weizenbock with the usual stuff.  Average
How:  Bottle 12oz, part of the 2011 Beer Camp Mix Pack.  Consumed approximately 4  months after it hit the stores.
The look: Cloudy glowing orange-blond body topped by a small white head
In long: Nose of sunburnt hay, a bit of bubblegum, light note of cloves.  Taste is wheaty, hay, bananas, bubblegum, sweet apricots, some cloves, yeast, phenols, sweet fruity juice from canned fruits.  A bit sweet.  Almost no hops presence.  Im not a big fan of weizenbock, and this one was just very average for the paler weizenbock sub-style.  One of lowest rated Sierra Nevada rating, a bit disappointing.  I will probably try this one again eventually and maybe Ill find it better, Ill always be ready to admit when I am wrong, if that ever happens.

Bottle: Poured a cloudy dark orangey/amber color bock with a good size foamy head with good retention but minimal lacing. Aroma of residual sugar and light wheat notes with some caramel also noticeable. Taste is a mix between some deep caramel malt notes with some residual sugars with some wheat malt. A bit low on ester for the style in my opinion. Body is full with limited filtration and good carbonation with no apparent alcohol. Not bad though I find that additional focus on ester with less residual sugars would be best.

Thanks to spinrsx for this.  Pours a hazy light orange gold with a thin white top that quickly dissipates.  Aroma is grain, a little sweetness and malt.  Taste is malt forward with a small sweetness thats great.
2011 bottle.  Pours ruddy orange, cloudy, with a small beige head.  Aromas of Bubble Tape gum, yeast, grass, and sweet fruits and berries.  The flavor is bubblegum and bitter grass/lye.  Meh.  [931]

(Bottle) Pours yellow to pale golden. The aroma holds bubble-gum, clove, bananas, strawberries, pineapples, pears and doughy wheat. The flavour is light to medium sweet and light bitter with juicy fruits esters, spicy phenols and wheat. The mouthfeel is soft and round with a near medium carbonation. Lingering phenols and esters on the finish. Medium bodied.

Bottle, Beer Camp mix pack, ty Kelly!  Again!  Last one from the mix pack and it is solid.  Pours a really nice hazy dark yellow with a very creamy white head.  Aroma is good - tons of clove and spice.  Mouthfeel is very tingly - medium carbonated yet creamy body that really brings out the spiciness of these hops.  Lots of spicy linger in finish and warming alcohol in the middle.  This is a very good version of a style I do not often go crazy over or reach for often.  Really well done.

text: 12oz.  Pours a hazy gold with a white rocky head.  Citrus and yeast nose.  Medium heavy body with a creamy banana bread flavor.  Slightly dusty dry quick finish.

Pours a cloudy orange with a white head. Aroma of hay, banana, cloves, orange and lemon. Taste is bubblegum, banana, cloves, spices, hay, yeast and little barnyard. Nice robust flavors and carbonation. Very nice balance. Some lacing on glass .Medium bodied and somewhat sweet citrus finish. Good beer would buy again.
Pours a cloudy orange with a frothy white head. Nose is banana bread, orange peel and yeasty spice. Flavor is sweet banana, oranges and clove. Medium bodied with a sweet crisp finish.

Appearance: a lovely orange, lighter along the edges, and topped with a generous off-white head  fading into a thick collar with spotty lace. Swirls bubbly but fades fast.

Nose: yeasty and doughy. Bananas and fuzzy orange fruits  nectarines and peaches. Aloe and cactus, white flower petals and stems. Tropical. Guava.

Palate: sweet up front then transitions into a summery tropical paradise. A bit mild. Banana peel, cactus, aloe  all in the back. Peach breads. Almonds. Dried apricots. Spicy yeasty dough. Grows a bit cloying. Spicy heat in the breath then dry straw and hay. Guava, aloe, and cactus.

Final Thoughts: it was alright and maybe it was just my mood but overall, rather underwhelming. Good but not worth seeking out again.

12oz, beer camp, bottle. Cloudy golden pour with an averaged sized white head. Aromas of bananas, cloves, yeast, and some smokiness. Tastes of bananas, spices, citrus, and wheat. Some bubble gum there too.

Not exactly an excited pour. Fails to raise more than a ring of white on the meniscus. Misty in the glass, the body a pastel orange with very little life evident. There is doughy ripe banana, fairy floss, cloves, smoky bacon?, creaming soda?? and rhubarb crumble??? coming through on the nose, very interesting. High gear for flavour, a no-holds barred onslaught of sweet, tangy and gammy fruit. Mushy ripe banana, strawberries, doughy guava and mango. Like a fruit slushy on crack. Finish is sweet, tangy and far too long with nothing set to balance. The body is not alarming, the carbonation nothing more than a prickle. Alcohol all but non-existent yet there is a vinous quality to it. Not my thing. A disappointment as their  weissbier helles is fantastic. (12fl.Oz, #109521625, Mane Liquor, Belmont)

The beer pours a hazy yellow-brown color with a white head. The aroma is full of caramel and bananas, with some brown sugar and wheat mixed in. It smells what I expect a weizenbock to smell like. The flavor is very similar. I get a lot of caramel-covered banana notes with some brown sugar adding some nice sweetness to the beer. The alcohol is well hidden and the beer is easy to drink. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

Bottle at Gallos as Beer Camp #37. The beer is a cloudy copper-orange color with a medium thin and somewhat fizzy white head that evaporates quickly to an outer ring. Spotty lacing on the glass. Aroma of bananas, wheat and malt. Medium body with flavors of yeast, banana, earthy malt and wheat. The finish is clean with a fruity aftertaste. Decent overall.

draft at Coles, Buffalo NY> Cloudy maize looking pour. Bubblegum, clove aroma. Taste is Bubblegum, heavy clove, lighter banana, sweeter intensified hefe. Somewhat boozy even at 6.6%. Pretty good stuff

12 oz bottle - served at the Bayou in SLC - pours a somewhat hazy straw yellow color with small to medium sized pure white head. Aroma has notes of clove, honey, chewy malts, touches of prickly pear cactus fruit, summer rain, lavender, and wet stone. Flavor has lightly chewy malts, with notes of lemon zest and coriander, very faint hint of clove. Finish is just on the sweet side. This is pretty good overall, but in my mind seems more like an imperial hefeweizen rather than a weizenbock. This is a very pale beer, and I think of weizenbocks as fairly dark (like a bock, but brewed with wheat and wheat yeast). I know that some weizenbocks are pale, its just not what I think of in regards to the style (Aventinus is my go-to weizenbock). However, this is still very good. I really like the aroma and fermentation notes, but I think it is missing the caramel and slightly toasty notes that are present in what are benchmarks of this style in my mind.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a hazy honey amber color with a medium sized off white head.  The aroma has sweet and spicy orange citrus, banana, yeast and wheat.  The flavor has some mild banana notes, sticky sweet malts, coriander with other spices, hints of citrus and yeast.  Good flavors; nothing too over the top.

12oz. Bottle:  Sweet aroma of yeast, wheat, spice, banana, cumin, coriander, and many other spices.  Poured a muddy amber in color with a small, loose, off-white head that diminished but lasted throughout.  Cloudy.  Sparkling.  Flavor is medium to heavily sweet.  Tastes of wheat, spices, sugars, banana, coriander, slight bubblegum, and yeast.  Medium body.  Tingly, then lightly dry texture.  Average to slightly lively carbonation.  Medium to heavily sweet wheat, spices, banana, and yeast.

(12oz bottle thanks to Dixonian) opaque gold-amber with creamy fine white-bubbled head. Nose of raisin, German yeast, cinnamon and other spices. Taste of wheat, bit vinous, raisin, umami, nice linger. Great beer!
Lots of banana and then clove notes, quite full in body, very drinkable. Slightly hazy orangey golden body with solid white head. Clove, banana and soft spices in the nose.

Bottle at home in NH, shared with Charlie, as Beer Camp #37. Pours deep, cloudy gold with a medium foam head. Big wheat and yeast nose with hints of booze. Medium to big sweet flavor, moderate yeast notes, candi, some mild tartness. Medium to full in body with average, lively carbonation. Mild warming finish, lots of wheat and yeast, candi sugar. Very nice.

12oz bottle.  Pours a hazy golden amber with a big rocky off white head that retains well and leaves a little lacing.

The aroma is subdued - some grainy wheaty malts and musty earthy yeast with some banana and clove and some floral hops.

The flavor is grainy wheaty malts with a little sugary fruity sweetness, and a musty earthy finish with some banana.  As it warms, the sweetness starts to overwhelm.  The mouthfeel is medium bodied with full carbonation.

Overall, its OK.  Its a bit subdued and a little too sugary sweet.  I dont really care for the banana notes either.

A bottle from the summer sampler.
Beer pours hazy orange with small sudsy head.  
Aroma is sharp wheat with some clove overtones.  The flavor matches the aroma.  Sharp finish.
A good beer, not one of my favorite styles... But still enjoyable as a switch up.

Pours orange/pale amber with a large, fading head.
Nose is sharply phenolic, lots of cloves and an almost medicinal character. Underneath is a hefty amount of doughy wheat and soft banana notes.
Very sweet tasting, with loads of wheat and confectionery-like sugary notes. The phenols are pretty overpowering.
Carbonation is much too high.
Pours hazy brownish orange color with off white head. Strong banana aroma with some clove. Banana, clove and bubble gum flavors with some wheat. Fairly sweet. Medium body with moderate carbonation.

12oz bottle from beer camp pack.  Pour is a very cloudy gold with off-white head.  Initial sips had banana, clove and spice flavors, as one would expect from a weizen, along with some citrus.  However, as it warmed up, some barnyard yeast flavor showed up as well, kind of saison in nature.  Interesting.  The carbonation remained fizzy throughout the drink.  The taste was sweet, with a bit of a sour finish.  A very nice beer.

(bottle 7/30/11). Clear copper color. Medium off white head. Moderate sweet bready malt/wheat aroma. Flavor of the same with very light hops. Avg duration. Light dry finish. Slick texture. Moderate carbonation. Fair lacing.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a cloudy orange body with a minimal fizzy white head that vanished rather quickly.  The nose is earthy and yeasty with a slight twang.  A little bit of esters and a slight citrusy note.  The flavor is OK, but theres not enough earthy and yeasty qualities.  It just tastes a little too clean and sharp.  Medium bodied with a little too much fizzy active carbonation.  No noticeable alcohol flavors.  An OK beer, but not a great Weizenbock.
Cloudy pour, orange amber colornice!  A different stronger brew for Sierra Nevada (6.6% abv).  Sweet flavor, banana taste, medium body.  Sweet alcohol finish, good beer for this style.

Pours an orange amber. 
Citrus grassy aroma. 
Sweet smooth flavor. 
Palate is smooth medium high carbonation. Orange finish.
Hazy copper pour with  a fleeing white head. Great warming wheat taste, at 6.8 avb this is not a session brew. ( a little too sweet)

Orange with a white head, and it smells a bit like a mimosa, or perhaps a creamsicle.  Taste is wheaty and sweet with the spicy phenolic huskiness into the finish. Good and persistent carbonation lends vigor to this beverage.

Hazy tannish orange body with a frothy white head...not much retention. Aroma of banana, clove, wheat malt, black pepper and lemon zest. Sweet flavor of banana and yeast, with wheat and herbal hops. Little bit of a bitter/peppery kick right after you swallow. Full bodied with a wet finish and strong, fizzy carbonation.

Very cloudy orange vanilla.  Good sweeti-ish aroma, a mild olfactory.  Strong taste upfront, perhaps a little more than the 6.6% would indicate.  Good real hefe backbone on an alky, banana foundation.  Bitter alky finish, not too sweet.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Bottle.  Banana, clove, wheat malt and alcohol aroma.  Cloudy amber color with moderate head.  Mildly sweet banana, orange, and wheat malt.  Light bitter herbal hops and alcohol finish.  Very nice.

It pours cloudy lemon white with a decent white head. It smells sweet with a bit of vanilla toffee notes and yeast. The flavor is sweet and a medium syrupyness that is pleasant. There is yeasty sweetness that manages to blend the wheat flavor/body nicely with a bock style.

Tasted on 9/9/11 from a 12oz bottle purchased at Grand Cru, labeled as Weizenbock Beer Camp #37.  Pours cloudy bright orange with a thick white head that slowly recedes to rocky lace.  The nose is full of wheat malt along with the signature banana and clove and almost a bit of a bubblegum sweet aroma as well.  The flavor has more of a caramelized orange peel note, but there is still a good amount of wheat with banana and clove.  The body is medium with an oily texture, average carbonation, and a long wheaty banana, orange peel, and clove finish.
Bottle. Sweet wheat , yeast, banana. Hazy gold with a quickly dissipating white head. Sweet, fruity/banana, yeast, robust malt flavor.  Spice in the finish. Medium full body. Really nice.

(draft @ Tap and Mallet - Rochester, NY) Cloudy gold pour with a thick white head. Sweet wheat and yeast aroma with a nice fruity undertone. Bananas and bubblegum at the start of the flavor with a very subtle wheat, yeast and spice middle. Fruity and sweet finish.

Bottle from Mane Liquor. Bright, cloudy orange pour with a frothy white head. Nose shows notes of clove, spice and pepper. Slight bubblegum and banana in there. Thick banana is the first noticable note on the palate. Pepper through the middle with slight clove and coriander. Loads of banana. Thick mouth feel. Solid brew

Best of Beer Camp #37: Weizenbock

Serving glass: Poured from bottle into Weizen glass. 

Appearance: Looks like thick orange juice with nice initial white head, which mostly recedes, leaving light lacing.

Aroma: Sweet banana and bubblegum, with light notes of wheat, clove and pepper.

Taste: Very sweet, with mostly bubblegum and banana (similar to the aroma). Ends with a light noble hop spicy kick. Not much refreshing wheat or clove characteristics.

Palate: Chewy body with moderate carbonation. Sweet throughout, even on the finish.

Overall: Great flavor, even if it is too sweet. Since I already knocked it slightly on taste and feel for the sweetness, I will be more generous here. But honestly, I expected a little more based on the Kellerweis yeast, which is such a refreshing beer.

Pours hazy light orange with small white beaded head.  Aroma is wheat, bubblegum, and banana.  Taste is of wheat and light malts with classic Hefeweizen yeast flavors including banana, bubble gum, and clove.  Its a little tart with bitterness on the front but ultimately finishes sweet on the palate.  Its ok.

From a bottle in the "Best of Beer Camp" pack.  Hazy dirty blonde with a medium un-lasting head.  Aroma of soft citrus, wheat, bread dough, soft herbal spice, maybe some clove as well.  Amazing aroma for a lager.  Taste is crisp and wheaty, with the citrus from the nose coming back.  But there is also this deeper biscuity tone, full of grains, soft fruitiness, chewy light malt complexity.  Arouses the palate with so many diferent things.  But its crisp and very easily drinkable.  Yet full bodied flavor.  Deliciously wheaty and biscuity and citric...amazing.

Tap at BT>  pours a hazed light yellow golden- lighter than many hefes- ok initial head then fades to almost nothing.  Aroma is very fruity- banana + other big fruity ester compounds, light wheat toast and slight phenolic clove.  Flavor is banana, wheat toast, doughy, slight solvent phenolic, and a medium finish- slightly sweet, and a little slick.  Ok overall, but not refined enough and overly fruity.
Pours a super-cloudy light orange. Overripe fruit, just a bit of citrus, some underlying caramel, and a bit of alcohol. Tasty, and a good example of the style.
Tap at Blind Tiger. Big,  bright,  sweet bubblegum,  peanut brittle. Sweetness overwhelms the palate, typical hefe notes with too much sweetness. Bleh.
Draught from el tigre. Poured a cloudy pale-ish yellow. Some malths and fruity aromas. Not bad.
Pours a very cloudy gold, with a white head. Aroma is banana, wheat, and yeast. Flavor is banana, spices, yeast, and wheat. Creamy, medium body.
Bottle - Beer Camp #37. Poured a hazy pale with a thin white head. Aroma of clove and wheat. The flavor found lemon, wheat, and light clove. Light body and a citrus aftertaste.

UPDATED: OCT 21, 2011 Poured from a bottle into a pilsner glass. About a half-inch of head. Lacing was slight on the top. Hardly any film. 
Just a slight bit of head, not even ¼-inch. Lacing was light on the top. Cloudy, straw color.  

Banana and cloves led the way on the smell. Banana bread in there, too.

Bananas led the way on the smell as well. Smooth feel on the way off the tongue.

Medium body with moderate carbonation. Flavorful and smooth throughout.

A good beer that grew on me as it went on. One of the best Hefes Ive had.

Pours a hazy reddish yellow. Small amount of carbonation, very yeasty. Bananna dominates the aroma and the taste but it also has some spicy notes to it, its a shame in getting stuffed up, and can barely smell it. Medium body, but it goes down super smooth, I could drink this stuff all night, despite its thickness.

12 oz. bottle. 6.8% ABV per the label. Pours a medium ivory head, of good duration,over a cloudy light amber (SRM 8) body.....nose is bannana, bubblegum, clove.....taste is strong banana, bubblegum, light clove.....mouth feel medium, carbonation adds a frothy character. This is a lighter less complex Weizen Bock. It has all of the right characteristics,but little of the subtly of the best. The esters really dominate, so I wonder if they ran the fermentation at too high aa temperature. BJCP 7/3/13/4/6

12 oz bottle.

It pours a hazy gold with a frothy foamy head. Looks pretty good for a Weizenbock.

The smell is okay for a weizenbock. There is lots of banana and clove and malt. 

The flavor is a little off for a traditional Weizenbock, especially one of only 6.8%. It is hot and boozy, overly fruity. The body isnt perfect either. Doesnt measure up to Bavarian examples.

From what I understand these recipes arent necessarily made by the pros, so it isnt as good. Good to tick though and not the worst beer.
Bottle - from beer camp sampler pack.  Light orange color - very cloudy. Aroma is malty and spicy. Pretty good - strong, spicy weizen flavor. Highly carbonated.

Poured from a 12 ounce bottle into a New Belgium globe.

Pours a cloudy orange gold color with a 2 finger sudsy snow white head. Decent head retention and lacing.

Smell: Banana, clove, lemon and sweet fruits with a touch of alcohol in the background.

Taste: Clove and banana up front followed by fruit esters and light bready malt in the middle before ending with banana and a touch of bitterness at the finish. Aftertaste is a mix of sweetness and bitterness.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied with a high amount of prickly carbonation. Goes down smooth.

Drinkability: Excellent drinkability. You could drink a few in one sitting.

Overall: Very good beer overall. Id rate this as my second favorite of the Beer Camp pack behind California Common. If you can still find it, Id recommend giving it a try.

Pours a bright yellow with a thick, persistent head.  The sweet banana and mango fruitiness so common to wheat beers is well balanced by the citrusy hops.  Medium in the mouth with a bright carbonation. Probably the best wheat beer Ive had.

Hazy gold with a nice, lasting creamy white head that leaves a good lace.  Aroma is mostly banana, slight clove, faint wheat, quite nice.  Flavor is spicier than the aroma indicated, with clove coming to the forefront, and a hint of gingerbread.  Slight banana.  Good malt backbone, some heat on the finish.  Perhaps not what I think of when I think weizenbock, more of a helles weizenbock.  But still a really good wheat beer.  Sierra Nevada is making the most "Germanic" wheat beers in the US today IMHO.

12 oz. bottle from Hayduke.  This pours with lots of suspended yeast in a tangerine colored brew.  A thick and long lasting head that is light golden hued.  I smell coriander and cloves with spices and banana.  The flavor is not as complex and offers hot alcohol that is prominent.  The flavor is spicy and herbal with some bitter astringency.  Fruit that includes banana and oranges.  Cloves and earth emerge in the finish.

Murky orange pour with a creamy white head.  Aroma is sweet with some honey and wheat.  Flavor is spot on for style with some nice banana and clove esters with just a little bit of sweetness and alcohol.  Smooth, creamy body with medium carbonation.  Excellent brew.

12 ounce Beer Camp #37 bottle. Pours a very cloudy orange color with a large sticky white head. The aroma is sweet peppery oranges, some lemon and honey. The flavor is a robust spicy and citrus flavor, some banana esters, light alcohol, a rich creamy palate.

Murky maize with a tall taupe topper thats rocky and fades away moderately.  Aroma of banana, caramel, clove, spicy yeast, lemon and mild alcohol.  Taste is malty and sweet with toffee, banana, caramel, sugar, clove, citrus and bready yeast.  Finishes up dry and spicy with a touch of warming and booze.

Had as Best of Beer Camp #37. Strong, wheaty aroma has a faint lemony undertone, a whisper of sweetness, and a lot of appeal. It pours a slightly hazy golden amber, but I was not able to get much in the way of a head. Delightful wheaty flavor has a yeasty underpinning and a hint of citrus that is more sweet than sour - quite refreshing. Texture is smooth and fizzy with a good amount of body. A good summer brew.
Pours hazy dark golden with a fair white head.  Aroma is of malts, floral, and some fruits and spices.  Nice taste, very floral, malty and fruity.  Very complex.

Beer Camp #37 bottle.  Bottled:  04/05/11.  A hazy pale rust-colored pour with a smallish light beige head.  A touch of caramel, sweet cereal graininess, wheatiness, lemons, bananas, orange rinds, coriander, cloves, and hints of nutmeg in the aroma.  Thin to medium-bodied.  Caramel maltiness upfront in the taste.  Cereal grains, some bananas, and a mildly toasted breadiness follow.  Orange rinds at the end.  A spicy finish with some pepper and nutmeg.
Aromas of banana and sweet malts.  Flavors of ripe bananas, cream and syrup.  Add a little chocolate and cherry and you have a banana split. Overall a very tasty beer.

Sampled at 1702, Tucson; August 2011
Arrives from the tap with a pale tan colored head that is about a half-finger in height.  The beer is a hazy, pale amber color that shows a really murky hue when held up to the light.  The beer smells of toothsome crushed pale wheat, a touch of green apples, clove, a touch of earthy grain character, some dried hay like notes and a general fruitiness that perhaps has a touch of banana to it.

Smooth feeling and somewhat thick as it hits the palate, there is a touch of a carbonic prickle from the carbonation and the finish has a big note of banana and then clove.  Chewy pale wheat malt notes, a touch of hay like grain, and some starchy honey sweetness.  There is a touch of yeasty (meaning the flavor of actual suspended yeast)flavors to this beer, but not as much as the deep haze might suggest, and it actually seems to get wrapped up in the chewy grain character that so defines this beer.  The Phenolic character in the finish has a hint of plastic character to it at times, though this is quite subtle.  I definitely like the chewy texture of this beer, it is perhaps not quite as toothsome as one might expect in a Weizenbock, but it is exactly what I like to find when I am in the mood for a chewy Hefeweizen.  There is also a hint of tartness to the finish that keeps this fairly quaffable.

This really seems more like a chewy HefeWeizen than I Weizenbock (this is lower in alcohol than New Glarus regular Hefe); I find that the pale Weizenbocks really need to be beefed up substantially before they can differentiate themselves from regular strength Hefes.  Still this is definitely quite a tasty beer.

Beer Camp #37, 12oz bottle: Pours a cloudy brass with a stringy-lacing white head.  Has a sweet wheat and floral lavender nose with some banana esters and a touch of black cherries.  Starts with good fullness and chewy malted wheat with a touch of lemon zest and fruity esters before a slightly drier bready yeasty finish.  Pretty true to style and well-balanced, but could use a touch more complexity and dark caramel notes.

Enormous overflowing head, gone three minutes later and thought my kid drank most of it.  Cloudy orange highlighted body, one-eighth inch retained head. Sweet malty aromas, and bannana.  Above average body and mouthfeel, good weizenbock, some bannana, a little pepper. Above average carbonation.Very drinkable.  Drying finish.Beer camp box, a good buy.

Bottle. Ill start by saying I loved this beer. It blew away my taste buds but not with just pure hops like an IPA, but with such strong, diverse flavors. Color hits between a creamsicle and burnt orange with thick haze. Nose has bourbon, grass, and hops. Initially the high carbonation dominates the mouth, then it switches to a hard hop bite, and finally fades into something resembling peanut brittle. Excellent, complex brew.

Wow, what a fantastic weizenbock beer!  This is truely one of the best wheat beers I have ever tasted!  It pours a beautifully cloudy dark golden color with an ample and soft white head.  The aroma is amazing, with notes of clove, banana, coriander, grass, earth and light citrus.  The body is incredibly smooth and drinkable.  This is the perfect beer for a hot and sunny summer day.  Its also the perfect beer for any other day of the year!  This is a full-bodied but smooth, drinkable, refreshing and delicious wheat beer.  The flavors are extraordinary, with smooth notes of banana, clove, wheat malt, spices and clove.  As I continue to enjoy this beer, I am speechless.  This is one crazy-delicious beer.  Truely awesome!

Hazed yellow/orange pour with a foamy white head. Brown sugar, peppery, fruity aroma, and wheaty malt. Sweet malt, a hinto of brown sugar, and a very light flat earthy bitter. Medium bodied with pretty smooth carbonation. A nice beer.

My favorite from the beer camp sampler.  A nice cloudy brown hue with a big white head that had good retention and mild lace.  Aroma had notes of banana, clove, biscuits and wheat.  Flavor captured the aroma beautifully.  Banana flavors up front mix with a nice doughy malt note. Cloves were enough to present but not overpowering.  Finish was slightly sweet.  Mild carbonation. Medium body.  Good beer.

Beer Camp bottle and served in my smaller Ayinger weizen glassware: Pours the expected hazy deep golden hue with a huge fluffy head and very good lace. The aroma has notes of banana, clove, pepper, wheat bread, biscuits, mineral water, floral and herbal hops, Nicely estery and phenolic, quite traditional. The taste follows suit with fruity and spicy overtones, wheaty and yeasty characteristics, very light hop bitters leading toward a slightly chewy finish. Again, very spot on for the genre. This is well played and something I would gladly drink again.

12 ounce bottle from the Beer Camp Mix Pack, opened 5/12/11. Pours a very hazy almost murky orange color. Medium sized creamy offwhite head. Decent head retention and lacing. Aroma of wheat, clove, banana and a hoppy finish. The taste is huge clove notes and tons of fruits including banana, pineapple and a bit of bubblegum. Medium bodied.
Bottle from the camp 12-pack:  Pours a hazy light orange with a huge white head, huge banana aroma, solid carbonation, starts and ends lightly sweet, full bodied with a metallic ending.

Aroma of wheat, sweet fruits like underripe strawberry and grass.  Pours murky orange with a big head.  Tastes of wheat, cloves, and a hint of cinnamon.  I love the intensity of the mouthful and it finishes fairly cleanly.  Yum.
Light in color, straw, cloudy. Aroma is sweet caramel and peaches. Flavor is burnt cracked wheat and prunes. Pretty muddy and not bright as I would have liked.
Hazy golden appearance, twang of alcohol, and bready, banana, and caramel flavors.  Very enjoyable and well built Weizenbock.  Part of the Beer Camp 12-pack.
355ml bottle shared by jsprime. hazed golden with a white head. basically an imperial hefe. thick and full. best attempt at an imperial hefe ive had.

12 oz bottle. Pours a very cloudy but bright orange with a small creamy white head. Aroma is very citrusy but nicely balanced with the creamy banana and yeasty tones, even picking up some vanilla and cream pie characteristics. Flavor starts creamy and sweet with that banana cream and citrus really coming out. Picks up some nice wheat notes before a lightly grainy finish. Medium to medium full creamy body and a soft carbonation. Really nice beer.

Beer camp bottle thanks to Jcwattsrugger. Shared with Yanick. Pours cloudy apricot. White head. Nose/taste of citrus, banana, yeast, lemongrass, wheat and light coriander. Dryish citrus wheat finish. Medium body.

Camp # 37.  Pours a hazy dark golden color with an off white head.  Aroma is of clove, wheat, grain, yeast, and leather.  Flavor is sweeter with malts, wheat, clove, yeast, booze, and aluminum.  Leaves a yeasty clove finish.  This is not my style of beer, so sorry if the score seems lower than normal.

This was the best beer of the beer camp 12 pack.  Pours out an orange color with a white head.  The smell is mostly all banana with a little bit of hops present as well.  Taste is incredibly smooth, drinks so easy it is almost like drinking a hefe.  Full banana flavor as well.  Really good stuff that needs to be put into the six pack rotation.

Bottle from SL, pour was golden orange with yeasty cloudiness (but not super heavy compared to other weizens), thin to light head for the style. The aroma was phenolic, bananas, other fruity esters, bready. The flavor was light fruits, deep fruity flavors though (peaches, pears even), bananas, phenolic spices with cloves most prominent, cereal, breads, faint citrus. Mouthfeel was moderate for the style.

12oz bottle, thanks wilkie.  Cloudy amber body topped by mostly dissipated off-white head.  Aroma is moderately sweet, spicy/yeasty, bubblegum, coriander, some banana.  Taste is moderately sweet, banana, spicy, some bubblegum, orange/lemon.  Medium body, light stickiness, acidity.

Hazy peach with a nice dense head. Aroma holds doughy yeast, banana esters, peppery and clove spice notes, and some orange/lemon peel. Flavor holds more banana, bread, and spice, and some really nice smooth fruit sweetness, like a sort of citric meringue. Nice soft palate with medium effervescence; good stuff.

Hazy nectarine pour with a robust white head. The aroma holds banana esters like mad with doughy wheat, and clove. The flavor is much the same- doughy banana yeast character with meringue sweetness and some coriander/ clove spice. The palate is light and quaffable with medium effervescence and a sweet clean finish.
Bottle. Pours hazy golden orange with a fluffy white head. Fruity banana yeasty aroma, with caramel and light spices. Fruity aroma, with banana, yeast, light spices, caramel, and clove. Good stuff.

Sierra nevada beer camp weizenbock 2011

5/6/11 @ azwine

Nice pale color....hazy honey

Big naner a +f , pale malt, spice, cereal, wheat.... Damn good and very sessionable. 

Medium-er bodied. Its got some oomph to it. Slight sweet but finishes dry
From a bottle poured a hazy dark copper color with a fair amount of head.  Sweet spicy malty flavor with a lingering aftertaste.
pours a cloudy yellow color. clear wheat in the nose along with the banana and cloves. taste is the same.a very pleasant wheat beer.

Sierra Nevada Weizenbock is a very cloudy, honey brown beer with a soft, thin, white head.  Theres lots of sludge in it.  The head thins and leaves nice lacing.  It has a Clove and banana aroma with notes of other spices, like cinnamon.  Its medium-full bodied and lively on the tongue.  The finish is pretty dry and it leaves the mouth a touch silty.  Its a touch sweet and quite fruity with notes of pear, apple and apricot.  A botanical bitterness emboldens the finish.  Theres a hint of lemon zest in the aftertaste.  This is a very tasty wheat beer.  It has a lot of flavor and its quite smooth.
A hazy, orange pour with a white head.  It has a wheat aroma with a slight fruitiness.  The medium body has a slick texture with lively carbonation.  The taste is sweet and refreshing.

12 oz. bottle from Randalls. Part of the 2011 Beer Camp pack. Pours a pale, cloudy yellow gold color with a finger-thick white head. Aroma of lemon citrus, bready malts, banana, and clove. Flavor of banana, lemon citrus, sweet malts, white bread, and candi sugar. Light-medium bodied, with moderate carbonation and a sweet, bready mouthfeel. Pretty nice.
Bottle. Poured a cloudy amber. Nose is yeasty and wheat. Hints of orange rind Amd almost has a belgian yeast quality. Finish sides on the bitter. Tastes like a belgian wheat. Nice.

12oz bottlepours a retaining foamy light tan head and cloudy orange/gold color.  Aroma is clove/spice, sweet light/medium malt-bready/nutty.  Taste is clove/spice, lemon, light/medium malt-bready, alcohol.  Syrupy up front, drying at finish.  Smoother at cellar temperature.
Nice weizenbock.  This is actually my favorite of the style made in the US.  Nice spiced flavor with light banana, wheat, and dough.  Really rich mouthfeel that makes for a silky finish.

Bottle. Pours a cloudy orange with a very large creamy off white head that lasts awhile leaving sticky lacing along the glass. The aroma is a clove yeast and bready malt. Thin mouthfeel with a dry clove and banana flavor with a smooth finish. Easy to drink a very good weizenbock from Sierra Nevada.

12 oz bottle. Deep orange unfiltered color. No head or lace. No carbonation. Great nose of clove and banana.  Made true to the style. Clove, banana, caramel with a slight sour note in the finish. As it warms up you can pick up a bit too much sugar. But I like the flavor and texture. It is a style I enjoy A LOT! I could drink large quantities of this.  A nice job from the Beer Camp.
Cloves and bananas. Wheat and sweet not as delicate as the German versions. Big and buttery. Pretty good but simple.
12oz Bottle pours out a cloudy straw topped with a fluffy head. Aroma was nice spice, banana, clove, toast malts, and some belg yeast. Taste was just as the aroma nice and full body.
had at the ice house pub sierra nevada beer camp sampling not my cup of tea but very good and smooth good beer

beer camp weizenbock - delicious beer. Very fruity, banana and clove esters. Orange pour. Pervading citrus note, phenollic yeastiness with a slight sour tinge and a hint of sulfur. Smooth bodied with tingling carbonation.

Bottled as The Best of Beer Camp Weizenbock (Camp #37).  Poured hazy peach with a creamy cap of white head.. looked great in the glass!  The aroma picked up toasted bready notes, tart wheat, bananas, and cloves.. all the usual suspects, and in the right proportions.. warmer toward the back, with a darker banana presence.. spicy and engaging.  The flavor found sweet bready notes, candied banana, and a hint of honey at the core.. tart wheat and black peppery alcohol around.. lots of residual sugars on the finish.. very tasty stuff.  Medium-bodied and well-carbonated on the palate.. good feel and flow, but just a few too many sugars for my liking.  I could drink a lot of this.

Very cloudy appearance with white head and a lot of lacing.  Smell is very enjoyable and sweet, but unfortunately the taste is way to sugary and kind of leaves a chalky aftertaste.  Dont get me wrong its pretty good, but the start is better than the finish.  Still, for a beer camp, pretty impressive.

Golden, fine white foam, heavy clove aromas, lightly creamy feel, bit of bittering hops on the end, light floral aromas, sweet, medium heavy feel.  Im not sure I like well textured feel here. Other than that, its very well done.

12 oz. bottle served in Weizen glass- poured a murky and opaque tanish-brown color, low carbonation, half finger off white head disappeared within a few moments, aroma of wheat, freshly creamed caramel, and bananas.  Hits the mouth with a medium body, malt is firm while bananas crash the party, a slight grass note in the middle, finish has cloves and very light lemon.  Almost perfect for a day in the sun.

Bottle. Cloudy, dark golden with white head. Aromas of cereal, vanilla, caramel, spice. Flavors of caramel, cereal, vanilla, spice. Slightly sweet finish. Medium-full body with soft mouthfeel and moderate-low carbonation. Best of the Beer Camp 12-pack.

Pours a soft bronze color with a massive billowing head. Certainly looks like a real German weizenbock. Big sticky lacing and good retention. Aroma is pleasant and sweet, with the classic banana oil note and a snickerdoodle maltiness. Lesser notes of grains and a very mild citric acidity. Flavor is quite silky and luscious. Nilla wafers and ripe bananas, less clove influence than Id expect. Theres a different spiciness in the finish, or maybe its more grassiness, which must be a noble hop accent. Honeyed grains sometimes come through, depending on the sip. Second pour yields more citrus and yeast flavors. Palate is quite nice; the body is perfect but the carbonation is a touch high. As it warms and breathes it settles into a very good beer. Considering this and Kellerweis, you have to put SN in the conversation of best American brewer of German styles. Very impressed with this beer, and Im glad there are a couple more in this Beer Camp pack. Just wish I could exchange the CA Common and the DIPA for more of these.

UPDATED: JUL 28, 2011 12oz bottle. Pours deep cloudy gold with a fluffy white head. Aroma is malty and wheaty w some banana esters. Flavor is strong  and malty with an unexpectedly strong punch of ethanol. Mouthfeel is surprisingly thin in body. Overall not bad but not great.

Bottle from the Beer Camp box. Hazy chestnut supporting a pillory off white head. Fruity aroma with sine bubble gum and a bit of hay. Flavor of toasted malt, banana, a bit of mocha and lemon zest. Body was just a tad thin. Long sweet finish with more banana.

From the bottle comes a hazy orange body that throws up a sticky white head.
Sweet aroma, candy and just a touch of fruitiness.  I dont really get any banana here at all.
The flavor is quite sweet with no hops.  Some alcohol.
A little too sweet for me.

12oz bottle. Murky orange with a thick white head. Banana and clove are nicely balanced in the nose. Taste is banana, vanilla, clove and rich malt. The beer is well balanced and properly attenuated. I really enjoy the yeast used in this one.

12oz 2011 Beer Camp bottle.  Pours a murky golden orange with moderate somewhat creamy linen white head that lasted beyond mid-glass and left a sheet of foam with each sip.  Very pleasant aroma of banana, caramel and a bit of wheat grain.  The flavor is again dominated by banana and caramel with just a bit of wheat grain.  There is a bit of alcohol flavor and heat towards the finish and was surprised to read this is only 6.6% abv.  Enjoyable.

My least favorite of the Beer Camp beer. Not that its a bad beer, Its just that it was so heavy and sweet and kind of a chore to finish. And yes, I do realize that complaining that a weizenbock is heavy and sweet is like complaining that an IPA is bitter. Anyway, it has a lot of brown sugar and molasses in it, as well a lot of boozy notes. Some vanilla, as well. Even a little bit of citrus as it warms. Thanks to unclejedi for this one!

Bottle. Cloudy golden body. Frothy white head, slowly diminishing. Nice aroma of sweet banana, clove, toasted grain, tart apple. The flavor is moderately to heavily sweet and lightlly to moderately bitter. It finishes moderately sweet and moderately bitter with some tartness. Medium body, creamy texture and moderately carbonation. Taste of banana and clove with some tart acidity. Wheat notes, sweet esters.
12 oz bottle.  Poured in a pint glass.  An interesting beer with nice co2.  Notes on lemon with a sourly-salty finish.  An interesting beer, but I probably wouldnt buy again.

From a 12 oz bottle from the Beer Camp pack. This pours a cloudy orange color with nice  beige head. Nose of fruit and spices. Medium body and smooth mouthfeel  Flavor is, fruit, mostly banana and spicy in the finish. Nice.

12oz Beer Camp bottle pours totally opaque orange copper with nice light tan head. The aroma is full up wheat with banana, cloves and apple sweetness trying their best to mask off a bit of lemon like citrus hoppiness and caramel sweetness. The taste is sweet banana and slick near creamy wheat malts followed by apples, pears and modest amount of either tart cherries or some lemon like notes cutting into some caramel. Pretty nice but it does get a bit too sweet after about half a bottle is consumed.
Pours a hazed orange with a white head. Aroma is esthers, bubble gum, wheat, fruits, yeasts. Flavor is fruity esthers, banana, spices, yeasts, malt, bubble gum. Nice Brew.

Serving: 12 oz. bottle from Wegmans Leesburg.  It pours a hazy deep gold with a well sustained white head.  The nose has a ton of clove.  The flavor is laden with clove and spice, with subtle wheat notes.  Medium bodied with mellow carbonation and a crisper, clove finish. A nice brew for sure.
Cloudy yellow with a medium lasting head. Nice nose. Malty nose and flavor. Nice job boys!

Draft Murky amber beer with a small, creamy, white head. The bouquet offers banana, bready wheat and a trace of lemon peel. Full-bodied and milky with jazzy carbonation. The flavor is mainly sweet banana and light clove. Finishes fruity and faintly acidic.

Pours a hazy orange with a medium creamy white head that had some lace. Aroma of mixed citrus, light banana, clove and a nice amount of maltiness. Flavor of lemon, orange, light banana, clove and a touch of toasted malt.  Good stuff
Bottle with Andrew and Carla. Pours an orange/gold with off-white foam. Smells of cloves and aged barley. Tastes include banana, cloves, soft barley and light honey.

Bottle shared by phaleslu. Thanks Peter! Pours hazy amber with a light off white head.  Aroma has hints of banana, yeast and cloves. Flavor is wheat, malt and a little bit of spice. Medium to light bodied with good carbonation.

Bottle. Hazy amber beer with a dark cream colored head. Spice and wheat aroma. Wheat and malt flavor with spice, light banana, and light caramel. Medium bodied. Wheat and light caramel lingers with spice and light earth.

Warm orange hue, white head that dissapates quickly with little to no lacing. Mouthfeel is creamy and thick, but smooth. I agree with the "banana milkshake" person. I dont really get clove but plenty of banana, yeast, esters and wheat.

Really lovely summer beer.

Draft at Whole Foods Coddingtown. Glowing turbid orange with fine white head. Appetizing banana with a touch of pasty wheat aroma. Sweet wort, mild clove, and distant dried stonefruit. A little chalky to finish despite the generous body; might improve with some settling of the excess yeast.
Pours a very hazy dark orange brown with nice amount of frothy manilla head.  Aroma extremely yeasy doughy banana.  Flavor overpowering wet dough with sweet sugary finish. Overall, not really a fan.

12 oz bottle from the 2011 Beer Camp sampler from my lovely wife for our anniversary. Pour is a slight hazed gold, with an eggy white head - well formed and quite lasting. Aroma is a nice grassy wheat, along with yeasty clove and banana. The taste is more the yeast, starting off with clove and banana, leading to an earthy mineral - bright gypsum.  The wheat and grass finish the beer off, with a touch of the banana, though less than the nose presented. Palate is medium bodied, though the unfiltered mouth feel, lively carbonation and dry finish make this quite drinkable. Nice balance.

Pours with a wonderful orange hue thats virtually opaque with wheaty-yeasty goodness. The beers nose wafts with big notes of bread dough and clove. Chewy texture. Yeast esters add hints of lemon, tangerine and light bubblegum. Zingy, attention-grabbing hops are biting, earthy and herbal, though theyre not overly bitter. Overall, its a rich, earthy and flavorful weizenbock.

12oz bottle. Toed for my favorite of the Beer Camp mix pack. Big malty wheat with a nice banana and clove flavor. Full, creamy body. Like a thicker, maltier kellerweiss that has been cranked up to banana milkshake territory.

12 oz bottle. Pours a cloudy orange with lacy offwhite head. The aroma is banana, clove, a little bit of apricot, and a sweet breadiness. The flavor is zesty at first sip, followed quickly by rich, fruity yeast notes. Typical banana and clove, along with a little bit of citrus and papaya. There is a deep crackery malt backbone that I find very satisfying. The finish is semi-sweet with an ever so slight twang to it. This is some pretty good stuff.
Pours a murky yellow with a white head. Aroma is bananas, clove, and citrus. Flavor is the same with a little added yeast and bubblegum.

Cloudy yellow orange appearance. Aroma of the yeast predominates with strong banana and a bit of clove and peanut. Taste is much the same. Cloyingly sweet with a hint of acidity on the finish. Nice full mouthfeel.

Tap at Redlight. In the .5 L weizen glass. Pours a yeasty light amber pour with a thick white head. Banana and clove aroma. Smooth malt body, lots of the banana clove popping through in the taste. Fairly spot on version of the style and a refreshing drink.

12 ounce bottle from beer camp 12 pack.  Pours a hazy golden-yolk color with a large 2 inch head that slowly collapses.  Taste is of wheat, banana, yeast, citrus, spice and some clove.  Has a similar, but very nice aroma.  The body is creamy and chewy, with a bit of alcohol in the finish.  Very drinkable and rather refreshing.  Wish it was in a 6 pack as it is well worth having again.

12 oz bottle. Very cloudy yellowish orange with a small white head. Aroma of banana, clove, grass, citrus and some bread. Flavor is tart and yeasty up front with a malty backbone and a touch of hop bitterness. Medium to light body with average carbonation and a crisp, clean finish. Not my favorite style but this is a good, solid beer.

Bottle on 12/23/2011. Pours a orange-yellowish opaque.  Aroma is of hay malt, a little bit earthy.  Taste medium sweetness, lightly bitter, malty and somewhat wheaty. Medium body, slick feel, average carbonation, with a medium finish, that is somewhat sweet and maybe sugary.

Interesting pour, there appeared to be a chunk or too along the way, and it was very very unfiltered, with a thick small bubble white uniform head, old school all the way.  Nose is typical but nice, ripe bananas, pears.  Full bodied mouthfeel, lush, creamy, smooth, with the yeasty sour taste, and a nice mellow finish.  I could feel the small bubbles tickling at various points.  This is really good, but take note, I may rate it higher as it is a favorite style.

Hazy orange yellow layered color with ivory foamage. Nice tart wheat, banana bread nutty smell. Medium bodied with a soft mouthfeel.  Good banana bread, caramel sweet flavors with some wheat tartness to balance
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: I find the aroma to be quite true to style.  Lots of banana, some esters, and lots of spices along with some yeasty, bready goodness.  Beer pours cloudy, dark honey color with a big, retained off white head.  Mouthfeel is smooth and quite lively (carbonated).  Flavor is sweet with some light bitterness.  Good beer.

2011, beer camp #37.

Pours a very hazy dark golden orange color with golden banana yellow edges when held to a light and a 1.5 finger frothy white head that slowly settles into a lasting cap. Rings and spots of soapy lacing left behind.

Sweet citrus fruit aroma with a ton of bready yeast and banana character as well as some zesty spice and earthy, floral hops. Hints of pepper, clove, and citrus rind. Subtle alcohol as well but the yeast dominates the nose.

Full bodied with a nice balance of bready yeast, sweet citrus fruit, banana and zesty spice. The yeast and banana characteristics are very prominent adding fullness to the body and balancing the spicier and sweeter fruit notes. Hints of zesty pepper and clove up front that linger into a slightly dry finish. Orange peel and lemon zest add sweetness and balance. Complex and full boded yet remains very flavorful and easy to drink. The best beer of the series that Ive tried so far. Recommended!

Tasted 6/22/11. 12oz bottle. 109521106. Pours hazy with a golden, orange hue. Billowing three fingers of dense white head. Heady aromas of bananas and citrus. Medium bodied with a very nice wheat flavor. A rounded palate and a mild finish. Decent effervescence. Bubblegum flavors mixed with the citrus zest and graham cracker malt/wheat bill. This is spot on stylistically and quite a good example to boot!
Hazy mustard pour with very good almost white head.   Good clean Sweet light banana, stronger on the  clove, vanilla, yeast flavor.  Pretty spot on for what i think of the style.

bottle-Beer camp series-pours hazy cloudy orange with a nice soapy off white head.  nose of over ripe bananas, bubblegum and fruity esters.  flavors of banana, clove, grainy malts, somewhat astringent husky notes.  long banana on the finish really not much else.  decent take on the style here.  from what i hear it uses the same yeast strain they use in their Kellerweiss.

Pours very hazy amber with a fairly small white head.  The aroma has candied bananas, cloves, rich wheat, bubblegum and cream.  Medium / full body thats very creamy with a moderate amount of semi-sharp carbonation on the finish.  The flavor is smooth, full and rich.  There are the traits of the aroma, but the rich wheat is really front and center and minimal banana, cream and bubblegum.  There is some plastic-like notes as well.  The finish adds spice and is a bit astringent.  Interesting beer.

Bottle sample prior to the SN Beer Camp tasting at Blacklick Wine & Spirits on 6/17/11. Pours a dirty opaque amber with a medium off-white head. Aroma of banana, clove caramel and malt. Banana and clove flavor with a bit of a peppery character before a caramel sweet finish.

(12oz bottle, 2011 vintage, courtesy of Mora2000)  Pours a hazy golden body with a moderate white head.  Aroma of banana, wheat, caramel, vanilla, baked apple, and clove.  Flavor of citrus, wheat, clove, and banana.

Sierra Nevada Beer Camp Pack - $16.99 at Total Wine & More in Kennesaw, Georgia.

Appearance: Pours out a clouded, grubby orange body with an initially lofty, white head.

Smell: Tangy and tart aroma of not-quite-fully-baked yeasty wheat loaf, clover honey, cloves, and dried lemon. Though, as it warms, a quality of cloves soaked in a clean, quality spirit begins to dominate.

Taste: Sweet honey suspectly dosed with a pinch more turbinado glazed over bready malted wheat preclude the expected elements of banana puddin, ground cloves, and a garnish-worthy lemon wedge. Small snippet of yeasty dough and Dubble Bubble. The unapologetically growing clove spiciness mingles with some slight tartness and a bit of alcoholic warmth. Slice of farm-fresh apple. Low bitterness. Tangy, semi-sweet, and creamy on the finish with a little lingering warmth.

Mouthfeel: Medium-plus body fluffed up with ample carbonation and the generous maltiness.

Overall: Oh, I quaffed it.

Bottle. Poured a cloudy neon orange-yellow color. The head was thick and off white with good retention and lacing. Pleasant aroma that included the likes of banana, bubble gum, pear, clove, and cereal grain. Medium bodied and slightly sweet. Cereal grain, clove, banana, flower blossom, and distinct ginger flavors. Somewhat reminiscent of a wit beer with coriander and orange notes.

Pours a hazy peach gold with a one finger, creamy white head. Aroma is wheat, tart orange, banana, wheat, dusty, earthy yeast notes, citrus, floral and spicy hops. Flavor is banana, sweet wheat, doughy yeast, clove, vanilla, floral and spicy hops, stone fruit, lemon zest and a touch of honey. Palate is medium bodied, creamy on entry, a little more slick in the middle and somewhat dry in the finish. Pretty tasty weizenbock, though a little lighter than most in every measure other than alcohol and body.

Kellerweiss  big brother. Its not easy to go bigger and still make it drinkable. All those flavors in a milder hefe get amped up in this beer. This is wheat that you sip on for a while. Really packed with flavor.

Bottle.  Subtle orange hue with a thin wispy head.  The aroma is of orange rind and yeast.  Musty and fruit-laden as any worthy weizen, this disguises or lacks any extra alcoholic kick, although at 6.6% it must be there.  Pleasant.  (#4142, 6/19/2011)

very hazy orange/gold with a thick foamy head.
aroma is 
banana and caramel aroma is very appetizing. some spice as well. 
flavour is bready, some honey/alc sweetness, wheat, light spice.
Very interesting.

Pour was hazy straw/golden color, with fluffy head and lacing.  Very similar in taste and body to Kellerweis, but boozier and additional fruity flavors.  Smooth mouthfeel and easy drinking.  I liked it.

Spicy aroma reminicent of cloves and coriander.  Rather light looking for a Weizenbock.  Cloudy in the glass.  Nice sweet maltyness followed by more of the same spicy clove & coriander.  Overall, Its ok if you are drinking one but not so much if you are having a few... maybe its just not my style.

THOUGHTS: Sort of light in color for a weizenbock. Even more confusing is the description, which mentions a dunkel. Very nice none the less.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a murky, light to medium, brownish orange with a hube, off-white head that mostly diminished and left good lacing. The aroma had light wheat and bread; heavy spicy and clove yeast; a little banana; and citrus fruits. The initial flavor was somewhat sweet and lightly acidic; while the finish was light to moderately sweet, moderate to rather acidic and lightly bitter. There was sweet malt, honey, white bread, fresh-baked bread, citrus fruits, clove, spices, yeast, wheat and hints of cocoa. The slightly more than medium body was sort of creamy and a little sticky on the lips with soft carbonation and a lightly astringent finish.

12oz bottle from the sampler, Sams, Durham. Yet another good one from SN, and I hope they continue to rock the samplers a la Sam Adams. Hazy pale orange pour, with a nice fluffy head (abundant mouthfeel is a treat too). Nose is fruity and estery, but not too much so. Theres a raw, earthy quality to it that makes the aroma more appealing than some others in this style. Flavors are bright, not cloying, and are well balanced overall. Keep it up, guys.

Nice, fluffy pour; yellowish white head on cloudy orange-gold liquid. Recedes relatively quickly, but leaves some sporadic lacing. Aroma of wheat and alcohol, and a moderate dose of banana bread. Soft palate, delicious banana bread flavor. Like Sierras Kellerweis, minus the clove, plus a bit more body and punch. Kellerweis is more drinkable, though, and this suffers from the possible defect of being to hot (read: boozy). Other than that, this is a very nice beer.

Thanks to BA abru17 for hooking me up with this bottle -cheers buddy!
Poured chilled from the short 12oz into a Duvel tulip.

A nice hazed amber like honey with thick cap of cream that settles to about a 1/2 inch with a microbead. The aroma is very full of banana esters and seems like a weizen in general with some light clove and mild alcohol odors, but very bready scent with yeast aroma the dominant smell. There is perhaps a tinge of hops in the background but very mild. The feel is good but a little sweet with full body and mild carbonation and gentle spice with a semi dry and light heat in the finish.

The taste of Beer Camp Weizenbock is lightly fruity to start- not as much banana in the flavor as the aroma and more creaminess than spice, but slight tanginess of yeast comes in with gentle pepper in the tail end. The light toasted and ripe banana leads to a slight flavor of alcohol and caramel as it finishes with a moderately sweet malt and yeast synergy. I like how creamy it seems with each sip letting you know you are getting your moneys worth in wheat and yeast. I enjoyed this particular beer and was satisfied with the Sierra Nevada attempt, but there are much better examples of the style out there. I just feel it is missing something...perhaps complexity
Pour is a cloudy orange with a average white head.  Aroma is lots of clove and banana.  Flavor is again a lot of clove with a nice juicy fruit and candi sugar.  A very tasty beer.

Bouteilles de 12 oz. Arômes de levure épicée (clou de girofle) et de blé. Robe dorée et très trouble, légère mousse et effervescence relativement active. En bouche, les céréales sont très bien développées, centrées autour dune bonne dose de blé légèrement citronné. Légère impression mielleuse. La levure est surtout épicée, mais apporte également des notes de pain frais et de banane mûre. Finale relativement douce, présentant une délicate acidité. Essentiellement une version un peu plus musclée de leur très bonne Kellerweiss.

Really tasty. Lots of juicy fruit with the banana and clove aroma, hints of peach. Cloudy as a spring afternoon, with a poof of lasting white cap foam. A little dry, maybe sour in the finish. A fun, flavorful interpretation of the style.

Bottle picked up at State Line in Elkton. Served in a Hill Farmstead long-stem tulip.

Pours a slightly-cloudy dark yellow color with a thin white head. Short retention time and not much lacing to speak of. Good thin cap throughout. The nose brings some nice banana and clove and a bit of bready malt in the background. The flavor mixes the yeast and malt quite well, with a nice clove spice to go with mild fruit and a bit of bread. Medium body with low carbonation; incredibly smooth and drinkable. No noticeable alcohol. Really a well done brew that is at the top of its style.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 06-16-2011

From the bottle, its full of retention, straw golden in color with quickly dissipating white head. I smell citrus overwhelmingly in the aroma, with dense underlying damp grass or barnyard aromas. This brew has got considerable depth of flavor; on one hand its juicy and sweet playing off of the lively effervescence, on the other and can be hearty and bready as it warms a bit and calms down. Delicious.
Bottle from Fort Worth Central Market.  Hazy yellow pour with a big white head.  Aroma is banana and grain.  Taste is clove, a little bitter, and lots of banana.

Bottle courtesy Fratto. Pours a very cloudy bright yellow color with a fizzy white head. Aroma is big Belgian yeast, with banana notes and clove spice. Slight bit of alcohol on the nose. Flavor is sweet fruit with some spicy notes. Pineapple type flavor that finishes with a life-savers taste. Slightly tingly.

12 oz bottle from Sherm1016...thanks....shared with George V.  Hazy orange with foamy full head...quickly dissipates.  Soft, wheaty taste with definite touches of various fruits....feels / tastes much like a hefeweizen...not sure of the difference....a definite summer beer.
Nice and sweet, full bodied. The aroma has caramel, clove, banana. The flavor is similar, very little bitterness. The finish is nice and mellow. Not for guzzling.

Bottle. Cloudy orange pour with way too much head, it foamed out of the glass onto the table.  Full Aroma, malty sweet, rather more than youd expect from a wheat beer, then this is a bock.  Malty flavour, sweet, with a banana, a clove and a citrusy note.  Sweet malt finish.
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text: hazy golden.  nose of equal banana and clove esters.  low bitterness before some munich malt sweetnes with the tang of wheat before the above esters are nicel present.  warmth from the abv with rather low residual sweetness for the style making this very drinkable.  very nice

really full mouthfeel.  very pungent aroma. flavor is sweet, banana, small caramel + honey.  i wasnt very excited by this and it seemed pretty by the books, but it is very tasty and satisfying if youre into the style
